1 §604 Definitions
Creates master glossary for the new cosmetic chapter.

Key terms: facility, responsible person, serious adverse event, safety substantiation, adequate evidence, small business.

“Facility” excludes purely retail sites and certain research labs; “responsible person” = name/address on label (manufacturer, packer, or distributor).

“Small business” ≤ $1 million annual cosmetic sales and ≤ 500 employees, but loses exemption if making higher-risk products (eye-area, injectable, internal-use, >24 h wear).

2 §605 Adverse-Event Records & Reporting
Firms must maintain complaint files for 6 years (3 years if small business).

A serious adverse event (SAE) must be reported to FDA on Form 3500A within 15 business days; follow-up medical info within 1 year.

SAE report must include full product label or photo.

Records must be producible to FDA “promptly” upon request during inspection.

3 §606 Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP)
Directs FDA to issue mandatory GMP regulations for cosmetics.

Draft rule due by Dec 29 2024; final rule by Dec 29 2025.

FDA must consider ISO 22716 and allow flexibility for small businesses.

Non-compliance will render product adulterated under FD&C Act.

4 §607(a) Facility Registration
Every domestic & foreign manufacturing / processing facility must register with FDA.

Registration content: FEI, contact info, brand names, product categories.

Biennial renewal; FDA may suspend registration if a product from that site poses serious harm → no U.S. distribution until reinstated.

Initial registration deadline: 1 year after enactment → Dec 29 2023 (FDA enforcement moved to July 1 2024).

5 §607(c) Product Listing
“Responsible person” must list each SKU and full INCI ingredient list; update annually or within 120 days of formula change.

Can submit by fragrance category instead of disclosing proprietary scent breakdown.

Listing number must reference facility FEI; failure to list = misbranding.

6 §608 Safety Substantiation
Firm must possess “adequate evidence” that product is safe under labeled use; may include in vitro, clinical, literature, history of safe use.

Animal testing not required but allowed if no alternative exists.

Records must be kept as long as product is marketed + 3 years.

Lack of substantiation triggers “safety not determined” warning (21 CFR 740.10 remains).

7 §609 Labeling Requirements
Labels must show U.S. contact (domestic address, phone, or web portal) for AE reporting.

Orders FDA to issue fragrance-allergen disclosure rule (EU-style list) — draft due June 29 2024, final by Dec 29 2025.

Professional-use products (salon-only) now require the same ingredient statement as retail unless exempted.

8 §610 National Uniformity
Pre-empts states from setting different registration, listing, GMP, AE reporting, or safety-substantiation rules.

States may still enforce identical standards and maintain existing bans (e.g., California microbead ban).

9 §611 Talc–Asbestos Testing
FDA must publish validated test method for detecting asbestos in talc-containing cosmetics.

Deadline: Dec 29 2023 to draft; final by Dec 29 2025.

Once issued, use of non-conforming methods may deem product adulterated.

10 §612 PFAS Study
FDA directed to assess PFAS prevalence in cosmetics and report findings to Congress within 3 years (≈ Dec 2025).

Study must cover detection limits, typical concentrations, and public-health implications.

11 §§613–614 Small-Business Relief & Appropriations
Revenue ≤ $1 M & ≤ 500 employees → exempt from registration, listing, GMP, records (but not SAE reporting) unless product is: eye-area, injectable, internal-use, long-lasting wear, or aerosol.

Authorizes $14 M → $42 M annual FDA funding FY 2023-2027 to implement MoCRA (inspections, IT systems, rulemaking).
